Remove this empty statement.
Avoid unnecessary zero-length array allocations.  Use Array.Empty<string>() instead.
Prefer 'static readonly' fields over constant array arguments if the called method is called repeatedly and is not mutating the passed array

CA1050.fullDescription: Types are declared in namespaces to prevent name collisions and as a way to organize related types in an object hierarchy.

CA1861.fullDescription: Constant arrays passed as arguments are not reused when called repeatedly, which implies a new array is created each time. Consider extracting them to 'static readonly' fields to improve performance if the passed array is not mutated within the called method.

CA1869.fullDescription: Avoid creating a new 'JsonSerializerOptions' instance for every serialization operation. Cache and reuse instances instead. Single use 'JsonSerializerOptions' instances can substantially degrade the performance of your application.

CA2254.shortDescription: Template should be a static expression
CA2254.fullDescription: The logging message template should not vary between calls.

CS8602.shortDescription: Dereference of a possibly null reference.

CS8618.shortDescription: Non-nullable field must contain a non-null value when exiting constructor. Consider adding the 'required' modifier or declaring as nullable.

S1116.fullDescription: Empty statements represented by a semicolon ; are statements that do not perform any operation. They are often the result of a typo or a misunderstanding of the language syntax. It is a good practice to remove empty statements since they dont add value and lead to confusion and errors.

S1118.shortDescription: Utility classes should not have public constructors
S1118.fullDescription: Whenever there are portions of code that are duplicated and do not depend on the state of their container class, they can be centralized inside a "utility class". A utility class is a class that only has static members, hence it should not be instantiated.

S125.shortDescription: Sections of code should not be commented out
S125.fullDescription: Commented-out code distracts the focus from the actual executed code. It creates a noise that increases maintenance code. And because it is never executed, it quickly becomes out of date and invalid.

S2139.shortDescription: Exceptions should be either logged or rethrown but not both
S2139.fullDescription: When an exception is logged and rethrown, the upstream code may not be aware that the exception has already been logged. As a result, the same exception gets logged multiple times, making it difficult to identify the root cause of the issue. This can be particularly problematic in multi-threaded applications where messages from other threads can be interwoven with the repeated log entries.

S2166.shortDescription: Classes named like "Exception" should extend "Exception" or a subclass
S2166.fullDescription: Clear, communicative naming is important in code. It helps maintainers and API users understand the intentions for and uses of a unit of code. Using "exception" in the name of a class that does not extend Exception or one of its subclasses is a clear violation of the expectation that a class' name will indicate what it is and/or does.

S3903.shortDescription: Types should be defined in named namespaces
S3903.fullDescription: Types are declared in namespaces in order to prevent name collisions and as a way to organize them into the object hierarchy. Types that are defined outside any named namespace are in a global namespace that cannot be referenced in code.

S6418.fullDescription: Because it is easy to extract strings from an application source code or binary, secrets should not be hard-coded. This is particularly true for applications that are distributed or that are open-source.

S6964.shortDescription: Value type property used as input in a controller action should be nullable, required or annotated with the JsonRequiredAttribute to avoid under-posting.
S6964.fullDescription: "Under-posting" refers to a situation where a client sends less data than expected to the server during an HTTP request, for example when the client omits some properties from the request body that the server expects to receive.
